### Table

Manual table

| Column 1 | Column 2 |
|----------|----------|
| Item 1,1 | Item 1,2 |
| Item 2,1 | Item 2,2 |

```{r load-data}

#read file into R
pop_data <- read_csv("data/gapminder_data.csv")

#create a table with data from European countries in 2007 showing the countries 
#with the largest life expectancy at the top 
euro_data_tbl <- pop_data %>% 
                    filter(continent == "Europe" & year == 2007) %>% 
                    select(-continent, -year) %>% 
                    arrange(desc(lifeExp)) %>% 
                    rename(Country = country, "Population Size" = pop, 
                      "Life Expectancy" = lifeExp, "GDP" = gdpPercap)
    
```

Include full table

```{r table}
euro_data_tbl %>% 
          kbl()
```

Pretty

```{r}
euro_data_tbl %>% 
          kbl() %>%
          kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover")) 
```

Paged table

```{r paged table}
paged_table(euro_data_tbl)
```

Default table - ugly, don't use

```{r def table}
euro_data_tbl
```

### Images
In Markdown:  
![Beautiful me](img/photo_5321516238851142298_y.jpg)

In R code:  

```{r patchwork}

p1 <- ggplot(pop_data %>% filter(year==2007),
             aes(x=gdpPercap,
                 y=lifeExp,
                 colour=continent))+
  geom_point()+
  scale_x_log10()+
  theme_minimal()

p2 <- ggplot(pop_data %>% filter(country %in% c("United States",
                                                "China",
                                                "India")),
             aes(x=year,
                 y=pop,
                 colour=country))+
  geom_line()+
  theme_minimal()

p1 + p2
p1 / p2
```

You don't need to do anything with the references, they are generated automatically (_isn't that lovely?!_)
